questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with low mood, excessive thoughts, decreased concentration while working, and sleep impairment for 10 days following a break-up with his girlfriend. On revealing his symptoms as well as his stressor, he specifically asked his treating psychiatrist to maintain confidentiality and not reveal his clinical details to anyone. Under which of the following conditions can his privacy be breached?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Confidentiality in the doctor-patient relationship can be breached under all the following situations:

  • Discussing the case with other psychiatrists, details can be shared about diagnosis and management (Option A ruled out)
  • In legal proceedings (Option B ruled out )
  • Homicidal or Suicidal patient (Option C ruled out)
  • Military courts
  • Child physical/ sexual abuse
  • Minors (details can be shared with caregivers)

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl complains of feeling depressed frequently and having nightmares for the last 4 months. On delving deeper, she revealed to the psychiatrist that she had been having these symptoms after one of her uncles molested her in an isolated place. She has not talked about this event to anyone (including her parents) due to shame and requests that the psychiatrist not reveal it to anyone. What should the role of a psychiatrist be in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • If a child has been the victim of physical or sexual abuse, then psychiatrists are required to make an immediate report to an appropriate agency. (Option B)
  • In this situation, confidentiality is decisively limited by legal statute because potential or actual harm to vulnerable children outweighs the value of confidentiality in a psychiatric setting.

Explanation for other options:

Confidentiality in this case can't be breached as the patient has denied revealing: (Option A) The duty to report overrides confidentiality in cases of child sexual abuse under POCSO.

Confidentiality can be breached only after taking the consent of the patient in this case: (Option B) A minor’s consent is not needed for reporting CSA under POCSO.

Confidentiality should only be breached if the matter involves a legal court: (Option D) Reporting is mandatory by law and not dependent on court proceedings.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Bipolar I Disorder, with a current manic episode and psychotic symptoms, is admitted to a psychiatric facility. Soon after admission, he becomes extremely violent, attempting to destroy hospital property and physically harm staff and relatives. Which of the following statements is false regarding his management under the Mental Healthcare Act, 2017?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chaining in any form or manner is a prohibited use under the Mental Health Care Act 2017.

Prohibited procedures under the Mental Health Care Act 2017

Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, the following treatments shall not be performed on any person with mental illness-

  • Electro-convulsive therapy without the use of muscle relaxants and anaesthesia;
  • Electro-convulsive therapy for minors;
  • Sterilisation of men or women, when such sterilisation is intended as a treatment for mental illness;
  • Chained in any manner or form whatsoever.

Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1),

  • If,in the opinion of the psychiatrist in charge of a minor's treatment, electro-convulsive therapy is required, then such treatment shall be done with the informed consent of the guardian and prior permission of the concerned Board

questions.text: An expert psychiatrist is asked to assess the testamentary capacity of a 65-year-old man who wishes to make a written will for his property. Which of the following symptoms, if present, would indicate testamentary incapacity?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All of the above symptoms would indicate testamentary incapacity,

Testamentary capacity refers to the mental competence required for a person to make a valid will. It essentially means the individual must be of sound mind and memory to understand the nature of making a will, the extent of their assets, and the implications of their decisions regarding their property after death.

Symptoms of testamentary incapacity:

  • Difficulties in attention and information processing (Option A)
  • Language difficulties
  • Memory difficulties
  • Impairment of higher executive functions
  • Persecutory delusions (Option B)
  • Delusions of poverty (Option C)

questions.text: A woman with severe schizophrenia is charged with assault after attacking her next-door neighbour with a shovel. She claims that her neighbour was a demon trying to harvest her soul. She can plead not guilty by reason of insanity based on which of the following legal principles?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The woman, suffering from severe schizophrenia and acting on a fixed delusion, may qualify for an insanity defence under both the M’Naghten Rule and Durham Rule, depending on the legal jurisdiction.

M'Naghten rule:

Determines criminal responsibility; holds that persons are not guilty because of insanity if they laboured under a mental disease such that they were unaware of the nature, the quality, and the consequences of their acts or if they were incapable of realising that their acts were wrong. (Option A ruled out)

Durham’s Rule:

It is a product rule of criminal responsibility, namely that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his or her unlawful act was the product of mental disease or mental defect. (Option B ruled out)

Model Penal Code:

Persons are not responsible for criminal conduct if, at the time of such conduct, because of mental disease or defect, they lacked substantial capacity either to appreciate the criminality (wrongfulness) of their conduct or to conform their conduct to the requirements of the law.

Theory of Moral Development by Kohlberg:

This is a psychological theory explaining how moral reasoning develops in stages, but it is not used in courts to assess criminal responsibility. (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: Only 1 and 2 are correct
Only 2 and 3 are correct
Only 1 and 3 are correct
1, 2, and 3 are correct

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman with chronic paranoid schizophrenia believes that her co-worker has implanted a microchip in her brain to control her thoughts. Acting on this belief, she attacks the co-worker with a paperweight at the office. She is arrested and charged with assault. During the trial, her psychiatrist testifies that she was actively psychotic and delusional at the time of the incident. Which of the following legal justifications supports her plea of not guilty by reason of insanity?
1. Absence of wilful conduct (actus reus)
2. Absence of evil intent (mens rea)
3. The delusion used in defence, if true, would justify the crime
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Under criminal law, simply committing a socially harmful act is not enough to establish criminal responsibility. For a crime to be legally valid, two essential elements must be present:

  • Voluntary conduct (actus reus) — the person must have willingly done the act
  • Evil intent (mens rea) — the person must have had a guilty mind or intention

However, in the case of mental illness, if a person's mental state is so impaired that they lack the capacity to understand or intend their actions, they may be considered not guilty by reason of insanity under the McNaughten Rule.

Absence of Wilful Conduct (Actus Reus): (Statement 1)

  • If the act was done without voluntary control (e.g., due to hallucinations, automatism, or psychotic compulsion), the physical component of the crime is invalid.

Absence of Evil Intent (Mens Rea): (Statement 2)

  • If a person is suffering from a mental disease to the extent that they cannot understand the nature or wrongfulness of their actions, they lack the guilty mind required for criminal liability.
  • This is the core of the McNaughten Rule, forming the basis for the insanity defense in many legal systems, including Section 84 of the Indian Penal Code.

The Delusion Used in Defense, If True, Would Justify the Crime: (Statement 3)

  • A delusional belief can be used in court only if, had it been factually true, the act would be legally justified (e.g., self-defense).
  • If the delusion does not justify the action (e.g., believing someone insulted you and killing them), the defense fails.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy alleges penetrative sexual assault by his tuition teacher. Under which of the following legal acts should the accused be charged?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act is a 2012 Indian law designed to protect children from sexual assault, sexual harassment, and pornography. It also establishes special courts for the speedy trial of such offenses and provides for related matters. The Act is gender-neutral. So, in the given scenario, the accused should be charged with POCSO.

The POCSO Act, 2012:

  • It is a comprehensive law to provide for the protection of children from the offences of sexual assault, sexual harassment and pornography, while safeguarding the interests of the child at every stage of the judicial process by incorporating child-friendly mechanismsfor reporting, recording of evidence, investigation and speedy trial of offences through designated Special Courts.
  • The said Act defines a child as any person below eighteen years of age, and defines different forms of sexual abuse, including penetrative and non-penetrative assault, as well as sexual harassment and pornography, and deems a sexual assault to be "aggravated"under certain circumstances, such as when the abused child is mentally ill or when the abuse is committed by a person in a position of trust or authority vis-a-vis the child, like a family member, police officer, teacher, or doctor.

Explanation for other options:

Children’s Act: (Option B)

  • Refers to older legislation like The Children Act, 1960, which mainly dealt with the care, protection, and welfare of neglected or delinquent children.
  • It has a limited or no direct role in handling sexual offences, especially after the enactment of POCSO.

Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) 22: (Option C)

It deals with the "Act of a person of unsound mind". It essentially states that if a person, due to unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of their act, or that it is wrong or contrary to law, then they are not liable for the offense.

IPC Section 372: (Option D)

  • Deals with the selling or hiring of minors for prostitution or illicit intercourse.
  • Not applicable in this case of penetrative sexual assault by a known adult (tuition teacher).

Reference: https://wcd.nic.in/sites/default/files/POCSO-ModelGuidelines.pdf

questions.text:
Which statements are correct concerning the Mental Healthcare Act 2017?
1. The suicidal act has been decriminalised
2. Advanced directive and Nominated representative are concepts newly introduced
3. ECT has been approved for use in minors
4. No restrictions on performing Psychosurgery
5. Chaining in any manner or form is prohibited
6. ECT can be used as a form of emergency treatment
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the Mental Healthcare Act 2017,

  • Section 309 suicide attempt is decriminalised, because those attempting suicide undergo a lot of stress
  • An advanced directive, which allows a person to modify their treatment options and a nominated representative can be appointed.
  • Use of ECT in minors is restricted; if needed, permission from the Mental Health Review Board is essential. Also, ECT cannot be used as emergency treatment. Similarly, performing psychosurgeries like lobotomies or cingulotomy is restricted without permission from the Mental Health Review Board.Chaining (physical restraint) is a prohibited procedure under this act. 

Reference:

  • https://www.prsindia.org/uploads/media/Mental%20Health/Mental%20Healthcare%20Act,%202017.pdf
  • https://indiankanoon.org/doc/117923983/#:~:text=Advance%20directive.,as%20provided%20under%20section%2014.

questions.text: A patient getting treated for a psychiatric illness inquires whether he is entitled to any special provisions from the government owing to his psychiatric illness. According to the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016, suffering from which of the following psychiatric disorders entitles him to such provisions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act 2016 includes four mental illnesses for which various government benefits can be availed (in cases of benchmark disability):

  1. Schizophrenia
  2. Bipolar Affective Disorder
  3. Obsessive Compulsive Disorder
  4. Dementia

The Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act 2016 explains “mental illness” as a substantial disorder of thinking, mood, perception, orientation or memory that grossly impairs judgment, behaviour, capacity to recognise reality or ability to meet the ordinary demands of life, but does not include retardation which is a conditon of arrested or incomplete development of the mind of a person, especially characterised by subnormality of intelligence

Intellectual disability, a condition characterised by significant limitation in both intellectual functioning (reasoning, learning, problem solving) and in adaptive behaviour, which covers a range of everyday, social and practical skills, including-

  1. Specific learning disabilities
  2. Autism spectrum disorder

Reference:

  1. Indian Journal of Psychiatry
  2. THE RIGHTS OF PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES ACT, 2016 ARRANGEMENT OF SECTIONS

questions.text: Husband and in-laws of a 24-year-old Hindu woman, married recently before 6 months, observe that she is not mentally sound; she requires assistance in almost all household activities, gets easily irritable and has poor self-care. They consult a psychiatrist who diagnoses her with Intellectual Disability, with having IQ of 44. After knowing this, the in-laws go ahead to file for marital separation. According to the Hindu Marriage Act and its amendments, which of the following holds to the above-mentioned case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Under the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, conditions in respect to mental disorders, which must be met before the marriage is solemnised, are as follows:
    • Neither party is incapable of giving a valid consentas a consequence of unsoundness of mind
    • Even if capable of giving consent must not suffer from mental disorders of such a kind or to such an extent as to be unfit for marriage and the procreation of children
    • Must not suffer from recurrent attacks of insanity.
  • Supreme Court observed that to brand the wife as unfit for marriage and procreation of children because of the mental disorder, it needs to be established that the ailment suffered by her is of such a kind or such an extent that she can't lead a normal married life.
  • Divorce or judicial separation can be obtained if the person has been "incurably of unsound mind,"or has been suffering continuously or intermittently from "mental disorder of such a kind and to such an extent that the petitioner cannot reasonably be expected to live with the respondent."
  • The expression "mental disorder"→ mental illness, arrested, or incomplete development of mind, psychopathic disorder or any other disorder or disability of mind and includes schizophrenia.
  • The expression "psychopathic disorder" → a persistent disorder or disability of the mind (whether or not including subnormality of intelligence) which results in abnormally aggressive or seriously irresponsible conduct on the part of the other party, and whether or not it requires or is susceptible to medical treatment.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4711231/

  • The age of criminal responsibility is raised to 12 years if the child is found not to have attained the ability to understand the nature and consequences of their act.
